pages:
STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 23, 2025
Mark Jones
Osceola Youth Center
3030 Long Lane Rd,
Evart, MI, 49639
Re: License #: CI670414130
SI #: 2025SIC0000644
Dear Mr. Jones:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Shay Mavis at (269) 243-2725.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
*** This report contains quoted profanity***
***This report contains sexually explicit information***
**AMENDED**
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000644
Special Investigation Intake Date: May 5, 2025
License #: CI670414130
Licensee Group Organization: Youth Opportunity Investments, LLC
Licensee Designee: Michael Cantrell
Chief Administrator: Mark Jones
Agency Name: Osceola Youth Center
Agency Address: 3030 Long Lane Rd
Evart, MI 49639
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 11/08/2026
Capacity: 16

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There have been multiple instances of two youth engaging in non-
consensual touching in the car at the park. One youth has been
smelling the other youth's undergarments in the youth's room.
Staff was present when the touching took place, but not aware it
was happening until after. One youth now requires one to one
supervision and both youth require line of sight by staff.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/8/2025. Youth A reported she touched Youth B’s vagina under
2

Youth B’s underwear while in the dayroom at the facility. Youth A
denied digitally penetrating Youth B. Youth A reported Youth B
consented to her touching her. Youth A reported staff (couldn’t
remember who) were handling a situation and did not see it occur.
Youth A reported she did not recall which youth were present.
Youth A reported she gave Youth B a hickey on her neck last
week while outside the facility. Youth A reported staff (couldn’t
remember who) were dealing with “another situation” and did not
see the incident occur. Youth A reported no other inappropriate
touching or interactions between her and/or any youth at the
facility have occurred other than Youth C slapping youth on their
butts. Youth A reported there was a situation in the van where she
was sitting in the back with Youth B and Youth C. Youth A
reported she was in the middle and Youth B was on her left and
Youth C was on her right. Youth A reported Youth C asked Youth
B which youth she would have relations with at the facility and
Youth B stated, “not you” and swiped her hand on the outside of
Youth A’s vagina to prove to Youth C she was not interested in
her. Youth A reported Youth C attempted to touch her while they
were in the van driving back to the facility and Youth A reported
she told Youth C to stop. Youth A reported Staff 2, Staff 3, and
Staff 4 were in the van. Youth A reported she provided the facility
a written statement of what occurred. Youth A reported Youth B
said she was going to make allegations Youth A did something
inappropriate to her so Youth A reported she told Staff 1
everything. Youth A reported she told Staff 1 last week on
Thursday. Youth A reported since she disclosed the incident, the
facility is now assigning seats in the van and a staff is assigned to
sit next to her.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/8/2025. Youth B reported Youth C is making false allegation
about her and Youth A. Youth B denied any sexual touching
between her and Youth A however reported Youth A and Youth C
had sexual touching. Youth B reported Supervisor would know
more information about this. Youth B denied Youth A giving her a
hickey or kissing her at the facility. Youth B denied any sexual
touching occurring between her and Youth A at the park or in the
van. Youth B reported she does not recall ever sitting next to
Youth A and Youth C in the back of the van. Youth B denied
anyone ever touching her vagina at the facility or her touching any
youth’s vaginas or any private areas. Youth B reported Youth A
was caught smelling her underwear at the facility. Youth B
reported she did not witness Youth A smelling her underwear.
Youth B reported Youth A told her she smelled her underwear
while Youth B was off grounds at an appointment. Youth B
3

reported she did not recall which staff were working the day this
allegedly occurred however Youth B reported staff should not
allow youth into other youth’s bedrooms. Youth B reported the
facility does not allow youth to have relationships with one another
at the facility.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/8/2025. Youth C reported Youth A and Youth B have been
engaging in inappropriate sexual interactions at the facility
including “having sex, vagina licking, humping, and fingering each
other”. Youth C reported the youth were all at the park and Staff 2
was cooking hotdogs and then later stated Staff 2 and Staff 3
were playing with Staff 3’s dog, and there was a female staff who
Youth C could not recall her name. Youth C reported Youth A and
Youth B were on the slide with their pants down and were
humping one another. Youth C reported she saw “hair moving”
and Youth A and Youth B were both inside the enclosed slide.
Youth C reported staff were not paying attention. Youth C
reported she witnessed Youth A “pull out yellow discharge from
her vagina”. Youth A and Youth B were kissing and then offered
for her to join them. Youth C reported there was another incident
in the van when she was sitting in the passenger seat and could
smell “fish, like sex smell” and witnessed Youth A “dig her hand
into her own vagina and pull-out discharge”. Youth C reported
Youth A and Youth B had their hands on each other’s thighs.
Assistant Facility Administrator was interviewed face-to-face
at the facility on 5/8/2025. Assistant Facility Administrator
reported he spoke with Youth C regarding the allegations and
Youth C’s story has changed as initially Youth C reported she saw
Youth A and Youth B engaging in inappropriate touching of one
another, then Youth C reported she did not see anything, then that
she did. Assistant Facility Administrator reported Youth C
reported Staff 4 was in the van when one of the incidents occurred
as Staff 4 was sitting in the middle row of the van and Youth A,
Youth B, and Youth C were sitting in the back. Assistant Facility
Administrator reported Youth C told him Youth A digitally
penetrated Youth B and Youth B digitally penetrated Youth A and
Youth A had Youth C smell her fingers. Assistant Facility
Administrator reported since the allegations the facility has
implemented a seating chart where he has assigned what youth
sit where in the van as well as all youth and staff are to get in and
out of the van at the same time to ensure constant supervision.
Assistant Facility Administrator reported when the youth go to the
park, the facility has now implemented for all staff to remain in
arm’s reach of youth to ensure appropriate interactions. Assistant
4

Facility Administrator reported he did not know if Youth A, Youth
B, or Youth C had any concerns of inappropriate boundaries with
peers at previous placements. Assistant Facility Administrator
reported Youth A and Youth B got in an argument due to Youth A
thinking Youth B liked another youth at the facility. Youth C then
told Assistant Facility Administrator and he reported he then talked
to Youth A. Assistant Facility Administrator reported Youth A told
him and Staff 1 about the inappropriate touching amongst her and
Youth B. Assistant Facility Administrator reported Youth B denied
the allegations and told him Youth A was making false allegations
to get her in trouble. Assistant Facility Administrator reported
youth do have small throw blankets they are allowed to use in the
common area of the facility as the temperature tends to fluctuate
and if the youth are cold, they are allowed to have their small
throw blanket in the commons area while sitting on the couch.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025
and a follow up interview via telephone on 6/4/2025. Staff 2
reported Youth A wrote a note alleging inappropriate touching
occurring in the van amongst youth. Staff 2 reported he had no
idea about the allegations until he saw the note. Staff 2 reported
the youth went to the park for a BBQ however he did not recall the
date. Staff 2 reported the youth were playing on the playground
and he was present as well as Staff 3 and Staff 4. Staff 2 reported
he and Staff 3 were cooking on the grill with some of the youth,
unable to recall who, and Staff 4 was with other youth, unable to
recall who, at the playground. Staff 2 reported all the youth were
in eyesight within a hundred yards of staff and staff were able to
hear the youth’s conversations. Staff 2 reported the youth ate and
immediately after eating, Youth A and Youth B went to the van.
Staff 2 reported he, Staff 3, and Staff 4 cleaned up quickly and
gathered the other youth and were in the van with Youth A and
Youth B approximately three minutes later. Staff 2 reported he
drove the van with Staff 3 in the passenger seat. Staff 2 reported
he did not recall if Staff 4 was sitting in the middle row of the van
or the backseat. Staff 2 reported there were six youth on the
outing including Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C. Staff 2 did not
recall which youth were sitting where in the van. Staff 2 reported
he did not know if there were any safety plans implemented by the
facility following the allegations as he did not see any safety plans.
Staff 2 reported safety plans are typically placed in a binder for
staff to review. Staff 2 reported Youth C told him on May 6th, 2025,
staff are allowing youth to “play with each other on the couch”.
Staff 2 reported he told Assistant Facility Administrator about the
allegations and a centralized intake complaint was completed.
5

Staff 2 reported Staff 3 brought his dog with to the park. Staff 2
reported on the way to the park they stopped at the gas station
and Staff 2 went into the gas station to get drinks for the staff to
have at the park while Staff 3 and Staff 4 remained in the car with
the youth and then Staff 3 ran to his house and got his dog. Staff
2 reported Staff 3 was gone for a minute to get his dog. Staff 2
reported on the way back from the park he drove a few houses
away from Staff 3’s house so Staff 3 could take his dog back
home. Staff 2 reported he parked away from Staff 3’s house so
the youth would not know where Staff 3 lived. Staff 2 reported
Staff 3 was gone for two to three minutes while he took his dog
back to the house.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 5/23/2025. Staff 1
reported at first, she did not notice any concerns with Youth A and
Youth B at the facility however then they began getting in “little
spats” and appeared to be pushing boundaries more. Staff 1
reported the facility does not allow youth to hug or hold hands and
she began noticing Youth A and Youth B trying to hug and placing
their hands lower on each other’s backs, closer to their buttocks,
when they would attempt to hug. Staff 1 reported when Youth C
arrived at the facility it appeared as Youth C was encouraging
Youth A and Youth B to become “closer”. Staff 1 reported Youth
A and Youth B began getting into more arguments with one
another and other youth, unsure specifically which youth, started
to allege Youth A and Youth B were in a relationship. Staff 1
reported she had several conversations with the youth regarding
how relationships are not allowed at the facility and addressed
proper boundaries. Staff 1 reported on 5/1/2025 Youth A became
upset due to Youth B and Youth C making statements regarding
feeling uncomfortable around Youth A. Staff 1 reported Youth A
requested to speak with her and disclosed she and Youth B had
been having consensual inappropriate touching of each other’s
genital areas. Staff 1 reported she spoke with Youth B after
speaking with Youth A and Youth B reported she did not want to
be Youth A's “girlfriend” and did not want Youth A to touch her.
Staff 1 reported Youth B did not disclose any allegations of
inappropriate touching occurring between her and Youth A or
Youth C. Staff 1 reported after Youth A disclosed the information
to her, safety plans were implemented to ensure eyes on Youth A
and Youth B and if there were any interactions regarding crossing
personal space/boundaries, staff were to immediately separate
Youth A and Youth B. Staff 1 reported she did not see Youth B
with a hickey on her neck however Staff 1 recalled being told
during shift change about something happening and it was
thought Youth B had a mark on her neck resembling a hickey.
6

Staff 1 did not recall when this occurred or which staff mentioned
this during staff debrief. Staff 1 reported Youth B would not talk
about the mark on her neck. Staff 1 reported Youth C was
crossing boundaries by slapping other youth on the butt. Staff 1
reported she did not see Youth C slap any youth on the butt
however heard Youth A and Youth B were upset about it and
Youth C was talked to about boundaries. Staff 1 reported she
made staff aware of Youth C doing this and talked to Youth C
about it. Staff 1 reported Youth C was separated from the other
youth at the facility prior to her leaving due to Youth C’s
boundaries and to ensure other youth’s safety. Staff 1 reported
she did not witness Youth A smell Youth B’s underwear however
learned about the situation. Staff 1 reported she walked into the
unit and noticed a youth laying in Youth B’s bed. Staff 1 reported
she asked Staff 5 who was in Youth B’s bedroom as Staff 1
believed Youth B was off grounds at an appointment. Staff 1
reported Staff 5 told her Youth A was laying in Youth B’s bed.
Staff 1 reported she immediately told Staff 5 youth were not to be
in other youth’s bedrooms and Staff 1 had Youth A leave Youth
B’s bedroom. Staff 1 reported Youth B returned later and told her
that while she was off grounds Youth A stated she went in Youth
B’s bedroom and smelled her underwear. Staff 1 reported youth
at the facility are not allowed to have blankets on the couch. Staff
1 reported initially youth were allowed to use their small blankets
on the couch however when it became a concern with Youth A
and Youth B crossing boundaries, the youth were no longer
allowed blankets in the living room. Staff 1 reported the facilty’s
supervision policy is for youth to always remain in sight of staff
and staff are to be able to hear all conversations. Staff 1 reported
she has noticed when incidents are occurring at the facility it tends
to be around new staff who are still learning. Staff 1 reported
when incidents occur at the facility, there is always one main staff
assigned to address the incident while the other staff maintain line
of sight on the other youth. Staff 1 reported she was not aware of
any times where staff’s attention would have been focused on
other youth having incidents where Youth A and Youth B would
have been able to engage in any inappropriate touching. Staff 1
reported she did hear Youth C make allegations regarding Youth
A and Youth B allegedly digitally penetrating one another on the
couch. Staff 1 reported Youth C made the allegations after Youth
C was involved in an altercation with youth at the facility (SIR
2025SIC0000655). Staff 1 reported she was working and did not
see anything. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 was on the unit working,
Staff 6 was walking behind the couch where Youth A and Youth B
were sitting, and Staff 7 was sitting on the side of the couch in a
chair supervising.
7

Supervisor 1 was interviewed via telephone on 5/23/2025.
Supervisor 1 reported no knowledge of any information regarding
youth inappropriately touching other youth at the facility.
Supervisor 1 reported as a supervisor he does not work on the
unit with the youth, so he did not witness any concerns regarding
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C’s boundaries. Supervisor 1
reported no staff ever came to him and verbalized any concerns
with Youth A, Youth B, or Youth C’s boundaries. Supervisor 1 did
not recall if there were any specific safety plans for Youth A and
Youth B regarding supervision and boundaries. Supervisor 1
reported he had no knowledge of Youth B reportedly having a
hickey on her neck. Supervisor 1 reported the facility’s policy is for
staff to always have eyesight of the youth and know what the
youth are doing and be able to hear all youth’s conversations.
Supervisor 1 reported youth are not allowed to have blankets in
the common area of the unit, including no blankets allowed on the
couch. Supervisor 1 reported no youth ever reported any
concerns to him about inappropriate touching happening among
youth at the facility.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 5/28/2025. Staff 4
reported Youth A and Youth B began becoming “close” at the
facility and began stating they were girlfriends. Staff 4 reported
she addressed Youth A and Youth B regarding the facility not
allowing relationships. Staff 4 reported Youth A and Youth B
would talk about being in a relationship however she never directly
heard Youth A and Youth B have any sexually inappropriate
discussions or witnessed any inappropriate sexual
touching/behaviors between Youth A and Youth B. Staff 4
reported she was at the park on an outing with Staff 2, Staff 3,
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E. Staff 4
reported on the way to the outing they stopped at a gas station
near Staff 3’s house and Staff 3 went and got his dog to bring to
the park with them. Staff 4 reported Staff 3 lived near the gas
station and ran over to his house to get his dog and was gone no
more than ten minutes. Staff 4 reported while at the park, Staff 2
and Staff 3 were playing with Staff 3’s dog and grilling hot dogs.
Staff 4 reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 were a little ways away from
where the five youth were playing on the playground however
Staff 2 and Staff 3 were able to see the youth but far enough away
where they were not able to hear the youth’s conversations. Staff
4 reported she walked around the playground area while the youth
were playing however at times, she was focused on Youth D who
she was attempting to build rapport with as the youth was newer
to the facility. Staff 4 reported she at times did not have direct line
8

of sight on all five of the youth as she was talking to Youth D. Staff
4 reported she noticed Youth A and Youth B were whispering at
one point and she reminded Youth A and Youth B whispering was
not allowed. Staff 4 reported Youth A and Youth B were playing
on the slide area however she never saw Youth A and Youth B in
the slide together. Staff 4 reported after the girls ate, all the staff
and youth were cleaning up to go back to the facility. Staff 4
reported Staff 2, Staff 3, and all the youth went back to the van
while she was finishing cleaning up. Staff 4 reported when she
got to the van, Staff 2 and Staff 3 had put all the food items in the
furthest back seat of the van and Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C
were sitting in the second to last row of the van. Staff 4 reported
Staff 2 was driving, and Staff 3 was in the passenger seat. Staff 4
reported she was upset with Staff 2 and Staff 3 as she had to sit in
the seat in front of Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C due to them
putting all the food in the last seat which did not allow her to be
able to provide good supervision as Youth A, Youth B, and Youth
C were behind her. Staff 4 reported during the drive she turned
around to check on Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C however she
did not have consistent line of sight on them due to being seated
in the row in front of them. Staff 4 reported she did not see any
inappropriate touching between Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C
when she would turn around. Staff 3 reported Youth A, Youth B,
nor Youth C reported any concerns of any inappropriate touching
occurring to her. Staff 4 reported on the way back from the park,
Staff 3 had Staff 2 drive to his house to drop his dog off. Staff 4
reported she felt it was inappropriate for Staff 3 to have Staff 2
drive to his house with all the youth in the van as the youth then
knew where Staff 3 lived. Staff 4 reported she felt it was
inappropriate for Staff 3 to have his dog at the park as Staff 2 and
Staff 3 were more focused on grilling the food and playing with the
dog than supervising the youth. Staff 4 reported she had no
knowledge about Youth A reportedly smelling Youth B’s
underwear in Youth B’s bedroom. Staff 4 reported youth were
going into one another bedrooms which is not allowed and
Assistant Facility Administrator addressed this with all staff and
reminded staff that youth are not to go into one another’s
bedrooms. Staff 4 reported she did not know if youth are allowed
to have blankets in the common area of the facility as at one time
it was a rule they could not except if it was a small blanket. Staff 4
reported she is not aware of any situations where Youth A and
Youth B were under a blanket together on the couch. Staff 4
reported the facilities policy for supervision is the ration is two
youth to one staff and staff are to always have eyes on youth and
always be aware of youth interactions.
9

Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on 5/28/2025. Staff 5
reported she did not witness the incidents alleged in the
investigation however she had witnessed Youth A and Youth B try
to hug, kiss, and Youth A slap Youth B’s butt at the facility. Staff 5
reported she reminded Youth A and Youth B about boundaries
while at the facility. Staff 5 reported she never witnessed Youth A
and Youth B sitting under a blanket on the couch together. Staff 5
reported due to concerns regarding boundaries between the youth
at the facility, the facility decided to no longer allow any blankets
into the common area. Staff 5 reported she was made aware of
the boundary concerns with Youth A and Youth B from
supervisors at the facility and was told to keep a close eye on the
youth. Staff 5 reported she was working when it was alleged
Youth A smelled Youth B’s underwear. Staff 5 reported this never
happened and was a story that was made up by a youth at the
facility. Staff 5 reported Youth B was off grounds and Youth A
went into Youth B’s bedroom. Staff 5 reported she told Youth A to
leave Youth B’s bedroom however Youth A refused. Staff 5
reported while she was verbally trying to get Youth A to leave
Youth B’s bedroom, Staff 1 came into the unit and was able to get
Youth A to leave Youth B’s bedroom. Staff 5 reported youth are
not allowed in other youth’s bedrooms at the facility, and she was
attempting to get Youth A to leave Youth B’s bedroom. Staff 5
reported Youth A was never near Youth B’s clothing while in
Youth B’s bedroom. Staff 5 reported Youth C started the rumor of
Youth A smelling Youth B’s underwear to cause conflict. Staff 5
reported the facility’s supervision policy is for staff to always have
sight of youth. Staff 5 reported she has no concerns with the
supervision at the facility.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via telephone on 5/28/2025.
Supervisor 2 reported he was not at the facility when the alleged
incidents occurred, however, he was informed by Youth A there
was digital penetration between Youth A and Youth B in the back
of the van. Supervisor 2 reported he was informed by Youth A
that Youth C made a comment about Youth A having vaginal odor,
so Youth A rubbed her hand in her vaginal area and asked Youth
C if Youth C wanted to smell it. Supervisor reported Youth A told
him about a month ago about the incidents and he spoke with
Assistant Facility Administrator who informed him the incident had
been reported to Centralized Intake. Supervisor 2 reported he did
not know if there were safety plans put into place regarding Youth
A and Youth B, he just made sure to watch Youth A and Youth B’s
boundaries and monitored them. Supervisor 2 reported he
informed staff to keep a close eye on Youth A and Youth B during
discussions with staff. Supervisor 2 reported small blankets are
10

allowed on the unit common area however comforters are not.
Supervisor 2 reported no knowledge of any situation reportedly
occurring between Youth A and Youth B on the couch under a
blanket. Supervisor 2 reported he has no concerns with staff
supervision at the facility.
Staff 7 was interviewed via telephone on 5/28/2025. Staff 7
reported he was not working on shift when it was alleged any
sexual interactions occurred between Youth A and Youth B,
however he was made aware and was informed to keep a close
eye on Youth A and Youth B. Staff 7 did not recall who told him.
Staff 7 reported no youth disclosed any information to him
regarding inappropriate touching. Staff 7 reported Youth A would
make remarks about a “girlfriend” however never specified who
she was referring to. Staff 7 reported he heard, however was
unable to recall who he heard it from, that Youth B had a hickey
on her, but he never saw it. Staff 7 reported he was talking to
Youth A and Staff 1 came and took over the conversation with
Youth A and he left. Staff 7 reported once Staff 1 began speaking
with Youth A when Youth A disclosed the inappropriate touching.
Staff 7 reported safety plans were put into place for Youth A and
Youth B to include staff ensuring appropriate boundaries. Staff 7
reported he has no concerns with supervision at the facility.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 6/3/2025. Staff 3
reported he was present on the outing to the park with Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E, Staff 2, and Staff 4.
Staff 3 reported Staff 2 drove the van, Staff 3 sat in the passenger
seat as the facility’s policy is for male staff to sit in the front or in
the back seat alone. Staff 3 reported the van has the two front
seats and four bench seats. Staff 3 reported Youth E sat in the
first bench row, Youth B and Youth D sat in the second bench
seat, Youth A and Youth C sat in the third bench seat, and Staff 4
sat in the second or third bench seat. Staff 3 reported on the way
to the park a stop was made at the gas station where he went
inside the gas station to buy paper plates and water. Staff 3
reported Staff 2 and Staff 4 remained in the van with the five
youth. Staff 3 reported once at the park, he and Staff 2 were
cooking food on the grill with one youth, Youth C was going back
and forth between the grill and the playground, Youth D was by
the water, and Staff 4 were with Youth A and Youth B on the
playground. Staff 3 reported Youth D was approximately thirty to
forty feet away from him and Staff 2 by the water. Staff 3 reported
after they ate lunch, the youth played a little longer. Staff 3
reported the youth were ready to leave the park and he was
packing up the van and told Staff 4 to watch the Youth A and
11

Youth B while he went to get Youth D. Staff 3 reported he came
back to the van and Youth A and Youth B were sitting in the third
row of the van and Staff 4 was outside the van on her phone.
Staff 3 reported he told Staff 4 she was not supposed to be on her
phone and was supposed to be watching Youth A and Youth B.
Staff 3 reported he was gone from the van getting Youth D for
about four to five minutes and Youth A and Youth B were in the
van while Staff 4 stood outside the van. Staff 3 reported Staff 2
was still packing up the food from the picnic area. Staff 3 reported
on the way back to the facility Staff 2 drove, he sat in the
passenger seat, Youth E was in the first row, Youth D and Staff 4
were in the second row, and Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were
in the third row. Staff 3 reported he told Staff 4 to move back a
row in the van and Staff 4 did not. Staff 3 reported on the way
back to the facility they stopped at the gas station near the facility,
and he believed Youth C moved up to row one in the van as she
was talking to Staff 2 and Staff 3. Staff 3 reported he did not see
anything occur between Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C in the van
on the car ride. Staff 3 reported he did not see Youth A and Youth
B in the slide at the park as Staff 4 was responsible for watching
Youth A and Youth B. Staff 3 reported he did not take his dog to
the park. Staff 3 reported on the way back from the park he had
Staff 2 drive three houses away from his house and park on the
corner while he ran to his house and let his dog out. Staff 3
reported he was gone approximately five minutes to let his dog out
while Staff 2 and Staff 4 remained in the van with the five youth.
Staff 3 reported the facility’s supervision policy is for staff to
always keep within so many feet of the youth however Staff 3 did
not recall what the specific number was. Staff 3 reported staff are
to always have line of sight on youth and be able to hear the
youth’s conversations. Staff 3 reported the facility’s ratio is one
staff to two youth. Staff 3 reported Youth A had to be reminded
often about boundaries at the facility as she would frequently try to
hug Youth B. Staff 3 reported Youth A’s boundaries improved as
she was at the facility however initially he had to redirect her
constantly regarding boundaries. Staff 3 reported the youth are
allowed to have throw blankets in the common area of the unit
however not comforters. Staff 3 reported Youth A and Youth B
were never on the couch under a blanket when he was working as
this would not be allowed at the facility. Staff 3 reported he was
unaware if there were any safety plans at the facility implemented
to address Youth A and Youth B’s boundaries.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on 6/4/2025. Staff 6
reported he is no longer employed at the facility. Staff 6 reported
Youth A and Youth B were “sneaky” and would try to sit close to
12

one another and would try to touch one another with their feet.
Staff 6 reported he witnessed Youth A and Youth B hugging at the
facility and when they would hug, they would “grope” one another
and touch one another’s butt. Staff 6 reported Youth A and Youth
B “were touchy/feely” with one another. Staff 6 reported the
facility put safety plans in place regarding Youth A and Youth B’s
boundaries however was unable to recall the specifics of the
safety plans. Staff 6 reported staff tried to keep Youth A and
Youth B away from one another due to concerns with their
boundaries. Staff 6 reported Youth A and Youth B would sit next
to one another on the couch however he never saw them sitting
under a blanket together on the couch. Staff 6 reported he never
witnessed any other inappropriate interactions between Youth A,
Youth B, or Youth C. Staff 6 reported no other knowledge of any
inappropriate touching occurring at the facility.
Chief Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
6/4/2025. Chief Administrator reported the facility does not have a
policy that addresses staff having their pets at the facility or
around youth. Chief Administrator reported he had no knowledge
of Staff 3 taking his dog to the park on the outing with youth and
Staff 3 was not given permission to do this.
Documents Reviewed:
• Action Plan for Youth A dated 5/2/2025: Due to
inappropriate behaviors, Youth A is to be closely monitored
at all times. Youth A is not to be seated next to Youth B at
any time. Management is to assign staff roles, set
expectations, monitor staff on shift to ensure close
proximity to monitor conversations and physical
boundaries, and ensure all incidents are documents. Staff
are to reinforce expectations set by management, confront
inappropriate boundaries and conversations between peers
and dock points accordingly, and report any
observations/concerns to supervisor on shift. Staff will
debrief with on-shift supervisor at the end of the shift. All
incident reports will be completed before the end of shift.
• Action Plan for Youth B dated 5/2/2025 was consistent with
Youth A’s action plan.
• Transport Action Plan: Staff and youth will be assigned
seats prior to transport with the understanding all youth and
staff are not to change the seating arrangement.
Appropriate spacing between youth is non-negotiable.
13

• Youth Opportunity Investments Incident reported for Youth
A dated 5/1/2025: Youth A spoke with Staff 1 regarding
sexual encounters with her peers. Youth A reported she
had been digitally penetrated by a peer at the park and in
the van on an outing on 4/26/2025. Youth A reported her
and the peer kissed on multiple occasions, resulting in her
leaving a hickey on her peer’s neck. Youth A stated she
has touched the pubic hair area of that peer. Youth A
stated the peer became touchy with her when she first
arrived after her intake. Youth A and her peer have both
stated they have been in a relationship on and off. Youth A
has stated multiple peers have touched each other
inappropriately. Supervisor 2 and chain of command were
notified immediately. Youth A and peers were informed of
rules and redirected on multiple occasions daily regarding
boundaries. Youth A was separated from her peers for the
night. Daily groups will focus on boundaries with staff and
peers.
• Youth Opportunity Program Description for Osceola Youth
Center Shelter Care: The facility is a non-secure program
that operates 24/7 365 days per year with 24 hour per day
active supervision. Youth cannot achieve successful
adaptation for the purpose of stabilization at this time,
without significant structure and supportive guidance that is
provided through twenty-four (24) hour intervention and
supervision in a highly structured environment.
• Youth Opportunity Osceola Youth Center Youth
Supervision, Movement and Checks Policy: Program staff
shall be able to account for the whereabouts of youth under
their supervision at all times. The Facility Administrator
shall ensure that the program provides a staffing pattern
that promotes “line of sight” supervision of youth at all
times. Scheduling shall ensure that the program meets all
contractual and mandated guidelines for required ratios and
the supervision of youth. Youth are supervised 24 hours a
day by awake staff. Staff shall ensure that appropriate
supervision of the youth is maintained at all times. Staff
shall provide effective positioning for optimal sight and
sound supervision of youth. Osceola Youth Center Shelter
14

runs at a 1:2 ratio during up and awake hours and a 1:6
ratio for sleeping hours.
• Youth Opportunity Osceola Youth Center Staffing Ratios
and Coverage Policy: Staff shall provide active supervision
of youth at all times through observation, monitoring and
use of an accounting system of scheduled, unscheduled
and emergency counts. Staff supervision of youth(s) must
include the following: • Remain constantly alert to the
facility environment and constantly vigilant to the youth(s)'s
activities. • Remain aware of and responsive to the
behavior and special needs of youth being supervised. •
Remain aware of the exact number and location of all youth
under supervision. • Remain aware of the location of other
staff. • Stay alert for any indicators of impending incidents
such as escapes, disturbances or assaults. • Remove any
obstructions that impede direct line of sight observations of
youth. • Avoid activities that distract staff attention from
youth supervision.
• The facility does not have a policy regarding staff being
allowed to bring their pets on campus or off campus around
the youth.
• Youth Opportunity Employee Handbook Security/Safety
Standards for Employees: While on duty no employee shall
bring into the facility any article that is not authorized by
written directive or prior authorization including cell phones.
• Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4’s personnel files: Staff 2 and
Staff 4 had no discipline and received training on Employee
Roles and Responsibilities on 2/3/2025 and Active
Supervision of Youth to include youth movement and
security procedures on 2/14/2025. Staff 3 had one
discipline dated 4/29/2025 for not following the facilities call
in procedure and received training on Employee Roles and
Responsibilities on 7/25/2023 and Active Supervision of
Youth to include youth movement and security procedures
on 8/3/2023.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance for providing “active
supervision at all times” per the facilities internal policy. Interviews
with youth and staff were inconsistent in regards to the
inappropriate sexual interactions that occurred between Youth A,
Youth B, and Youth C however in interviews with youth and staff,
15

it was clear staff did not provide “active supervision at all times”
per the facilities policy as the facility’s policy states “line of sight
supervision at all times”, for staff to be constantly alert, aware of
behaviors, remove any obstructions that impede direct line of
sight, and avoid activities that distract staff attention from youth
supervision. Per interviews, Staff 3 had his dog at the park on the
outing and reportedly Staff 2 and Staff 3 were playing with the dog
and cooking the food which distracted Staff 2 and Staff 3 from
providing supervision, staff were cleaning up from the picnic and
putting items back in the van while youth were in various locations
in the park including Youth D near the water, Staff 4 was
reportedly on her cellphone outside the van while Youth A and
Youth B were in the van unsupervised, Youth A, Youth B, and
Youth C were seated behind Staff 4 in the van where Staff 4 was
unable to maintain line of sight, and per Youth A's interview she
reported engaging in consensual touching with Youth B on the
couch while staff were addressing another youth’s behavior.
CONSULTATION:
• Consultation was offered for the facility to implement a
system to communicate safety plans amongst staff as per
interviews with staff, some staff reported not being aware if
any safety plans were in place regarding Youth A and
Youth B’s boundaries. Staff reported several observations
of concerns with Youth A and Youth B’s boundaries
however it did not appear safety plans were implemented
until after the incidents occurred although there were
warning signs prior.
• Consultation was offered for the facility to implement a
communication system to ensure supervisors are informed
on dynamics occurring at the facility to ensure supervisors
are able to communicate all concerns and direct staff in
terms of concerns and expectations as per interview with
Supervisor 1, Supervisor 1 reported no knowledge of any
boundary concerns and reported lack of information due to
not being on the floor and knowledgeable on youth
dynamics.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• The facility retrain staff on supervision expectations.
• The facility address allowing youth to have blankets in the
common areas of the facility as per interviews with staff it
appears as it is unclear as some say it is allowed and
others reported it is not.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
16

SIR 2025SIC0000509 dated 5/15/2025, CAP Approved 6/9/2025
SIR 2024SIC0001561 dated 8/27/2024, CAP Approved 9/24/2024
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law;
Section development of plan required.
Description (1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff did not report these concerns to Centralized Intake or Law
Enforcement. One of the youth was digitally penetrated by a third
youth on the playground.
Investigation Interviews:
Assistant Facility Administrator was interviewed face-to-face
at the facility on 5/8/2025. Assistant Facility Administrator
reported he became aware of the incident last week but was not
sure which day. Assistant Facility Administrator reported the
facilities Mandated Reporter Policy is to get all the information and
report the information to Centralized Intake. Assistant Facility
Administrator reported he did not report the information to
Centralized Intake as he thought it had already been reported by
Staff 1. Assistant Facility Administrator reported Staff 1 was
followed up with to ensure she reported the incident at which time
Staff 1 stated she did. Assistant Facility Administrator did not
know when Staff 1 reported the information to Centralized Intake.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 5/23/2025. Staff 1
reported she completed an incident reported on 5/1/2025 after
Youth A disclosed inappropriate touching amongst youth. Staff 1
reported she completed a report to Centralized Intake on
5/3/2025. Staff 1 reported she was confused on the reporting
requirements as the incident occurred at the facility and she
believed completing the incident report was all she needed to do
for administration to start a PREA (Prison Rape Elimination Act)
investigation and administration would call the incident in to
Centralized Intake. Staff 1 reported Assistant Facility
Administrator asked her if she had called in the report, and she
informed him she had not as she thought administration would call
the incident in based on the incident report. Staff 1 reported
Assistant Facilities Administrator informed her she had to call in
the complaint at which time she did. Staff 1 reported this was the
first experience she had with an allegation at the facility and did
not know the reporting requirements for incidents when they
occurred at the facility.
17

Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 6/3/2025. Staff 3
reported he became aware of inappropriate touching occurring
between Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C when Youth B disclosed
to him a day or two after the park outing. Staff 3 reported Youth B
told him when she was in the van with Youth A and Youth C, they
were talking about their “private parts” and were “trying to show
each other” their “private parts”. Staff 3 reported Youth B told him
she “showed herself” to Youth A and Youth C and Youth A, Youth
B, and Youth C “touched each other”. Staff 3 reported he told
Medical and Assistant Facility Administrator and wrote an incident
report.
Medical Management was interviewed via telephone on
6/4/2025. Medical Management reported she became aware of
the inappropriate touching occurring between youth when Staff 3
came to her and informed her Youth B disclosed youth were
touching one another and Youth B reported she felt pressured.
Medical Management reported she did not recall the specifics of
the conversation, or the date Staff 3 came to her. Medical
Management reported she informed Staff 3 to contact Assistant
Facility Administrator immediately and Staff 3 did. Medical
Management reported she did not know if an incident report was
completed.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth Opportunity Osceola Youth Center Provision of an
Abuse Free Environment, Youth Rights, Plan for adherence
with Child Protection Law MCL 722.621-722.638: All staff,
volunteers, interns and contracted staff who have
knowledge, or reasonable cause to suspect that a child is
being abused or neglected shall report that information to
the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
Centralized Intake(1-855-444-3911). Once the call has
been completed, staff must notify the Facility Administrator
or supervisor on duty as soon as possible. The Facility
Administrator or supervisor shall begin an immediate
review. The written 3200 shall be completed within 24
hours of verbal report.
• Youth Opportunity Investments Incident reported for Youth
A dated 5/1/2025: Youth A reported to Staff 1 sexual
actions between her and another youth at the facility.
18

• Consultant requested the incident report Staff 3 indicated
he wrote however the facility was unable to locate the
incident report.
• Staff 1 and Staff 3’s personnel files: Staff 1 had no
discipline and received training on Child Abuse:
Recognition, Reporting, and Prevention during orientation
training on 6/21/2024. Staff 3 had one discipline dated
4/29/2024 due to call in procedure not being followed and
received training on Child Abuse: Recognition, Reporting,
and Prevention during orientation training on 7/25/2023.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Staff 1 was informed by
Youth A of the sexually inappropriate touching occurring between
youth on 5/1/2025 and did not follow the facilities internal policy of
reporting the suspected abuse or neglect to MDHHS Centralized
Intake immediately as she reported she was confused about the
process and called in the complaint to Centralized Intake on
5/3/2025 after Assistant Facility Administrator informed her to.
Staff 3 reported Youth B disclosed information to him about the
inappropriate sexual touching occurring and did not report this
information to Centralized Intake.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered to retrain staff on mandated
reporter responsibilities and the facility’s policy regarding reporting
concerns of suspected abuse and/or neglect.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2023C0000770SI dated 10/20/23, CAP Approved 11/16/23
SIR 2025SIC0000567 dated 6/5/2025, CAP Pending
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (3) The ratio formula for direct care workers shall correspond with
Description the institution's purpose and the needs of the residents and shall
assure the continual safety, protection, and direct care and
supervision of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The facility did not maintain ratio of one staff to two youth.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 5/28/2025. Staff 4
reported she was at the park on an outing with Staff 2, Staff 3,
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E. Staff 4
reported on the way to the outing they stopped at a gas station
near Staff 3’s house and Staff 3 went and got his dog to bring to
the park with them. Staff 4 reported Staff 3 lived near the gas
19

station and ran over to his house to get his dog and was gone no
more that ten minutes. Staff 4 reported on the way back from the
park, Staff 3 had Staff 2 drive to his house to drop his dog off.
Staff 4 reported the facility’s policy for ratio is two youth to one
staff.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 6/3/2025. Staff 3
reported he was present on the outing to the park with Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E, Staff 2, and Staff 4.
Staff 3 reported on the way to the park a stop was made at the
gas station where he went inside the gas station to buy paper
plates and water. Staff 3 reported Staff 2 and Staff 4 remained in
the van with the five youth. Staff 3 reported on the way back from
the park he had Staff 2 drive three houses away from his house
and park on the corner while he ran to his house and let his dog
out. Staff 3 reported he was gone approximately five minutes to
let his dog out while Staff 2 and Staff 4 remained in the van with
the five youth. Staff 3 reported the facility’s supervision policy is
for staff to always keep within so many feet of the youth however
Staff 3 did not recall what the specific number was. Staff 3
reported staff are to always have line of sight on youth and be
able to hear the youth’s conversations. Staff 3 reported the
facility’s ratio is one staff to two youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025
and a follow up interview via telephone on 6/4/2025. Staff 2
reported Staff 3 brought his dog with to the park. Staff 2 reported
on the way to the park they stopped at the gas station and Staff 2
went into the gas station to get drinks for the staff to have at the
park while Staff 3 and Staff 4 remained in the car with the youth.
Staff 2 reported he was in the gas station for two to three minutes.
Staff 2 reported Staff 3 ran to his house and got his dog. Staff 2
reported Staff 3 was gone for a minute to get his dog. Staff 2
reported on the way back from the park he drove a few houses
away from Staff 3’s house so Staff 3 could take his dog back
home. Staff 2 reported he parked away from Staff 3’s house so
the youth would not know where Staff 3 lived. Staff 2 reported
Staff 3 was gone for two to three minutes while he took his dog
back to the house. Staff 2 reported he did not recall if there were
four or five youth who were on the outing to go to the park. Staff 2
reported the facility’s ratio is one staff to two youth.
Chief Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
6/4/2025. Chief Administrator reported the facility ratio is always
1:2 for the girl’s shelter program; the ratio is not 1:3 for off grounds
activities.
20

Documents Reviewed:
• Youth Opportunity Osceola Youth Center Staffing Ratios
and Coverage Policy: Osceola Youth Center shall ensure
the required staff to youth ratio is maintained at all times in
accordance with contract to provide for active supervision
of youth and effective service delivery. The program’s staff
to youth ratio for shelter care is 1:2 awake and 1:6 sleeping
hours. All off grounds activities have a 1:3 ratio.
• Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4’s personnel files: Staff 2 and
Staff 4 had no discipline and received training on Employee
Roles and Responsibilities on 2/3/2025 and Active
Supervision of Youth to include youth movement and
security procedures on 2/14/2025. Staff 3 had one
discipline dated 4/29/2025 for not following the facilities call
in procedure and received training on Employee Roles and
Responsibilities on 7/25/2023 and Active Supervision of
Youth to include youth movement and security procedures
on 8/3/2023.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as the facility’s policy indicates
the off-grounds ratio is 1:3, and staff maintained that ratio during
their trip to the park.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• Technical assistance was offered to retrain staff on the
facilities ratio and expectation of staff to always remain in
ratio.
• Technical assistance was offered to the facility to update
the Staffing Ratios and Coverage Policy as the policy
indicates all off grounds activities has a ratio of 1:3 but
Chief Administrator reported they maintain a 1:2 ratio for
off-grounds activities, and the policy should reflect the 1:2
ratio.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
21

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
